div.p: Industrialist, chocolate manufacturer, possibly German; long-time pupil of Schenker's.

Dr. Robert Brünauer owned and managed a chocolate manufacturing company. Nothing is known of him or his company. From Schenker's diary, we know that c. 1907 he was married and lived in Heiligenstadt (OJ 1/6, p. 44), that he did not have to do military service in World War I, that his marriage had evidently broken up by 1919, when his wife and children were living in Berlin (OJ 2/14, p. 2051), that he re-married in September or October 1920 (OJ 3/1, p. 2279), and that this wife left him in 1923 (OJ 3/4, p. 2512). We also know that his "family" were living in Tutzing, Germany, around 1914, though whether this was his first wife and childen or his own blood relatives is not clear.

div.head: Brünauer and Schenker
div.p: Schenker first entered the Brünauer home on October 4, 1902; he became a regular visitor thereafter and often went to the theater and concerts with Brünauer, sometimes together with the latter's first wife. Brünauer had become a pupil by October 1906, when he embarked on study of the Beethoven Sonata Op. 109 with Schenker. He was still a regular pupil in the last surviving lessonbook, 1930/31, and the draft lesson notes for 1931/32 (OC 3/1-4; OC 16/19-24, 47). He thus belongs with Angelika Elias and Marianne Kahn (who herself gave piano lessons to Brünauer's mother), who began lessons with Schenker in the mid-1900s and apparently continued until Schenker's death. He also belongs with Sofie Deutsch, who was taking lessons from c. 1902, and whose house he frequently visited along with Schenker.

Brünauer was evidently generous to Heinrich and Jeanette, supplying them with candy (which, since Schenker was diabetic, they seem to have used for barter), and in 1918 offered Schenker 5,000 Kronen to assist with the publishing costs of Kontrapunkt 2 (which Schenker rejected because Elias had already offered more for the same purpose: OJ 2/10, pp. 896–97, 898, June 1, 1918). He was also involved that year in the abortive plan for a Festschrift to mark Schenker's 50th birthday. It was Brünauer, too, who suggested to Schenker that he sit for the artist Viktor Hammer (OJ 2/10, pp. 900–01, June 11, 1918). Contrarily, he was often late in paying his fees, sometimes paying at the previous year's rate and having to be reprimanded. Thus Schenker had an ambivalent relationship with him. The two men had frequent conversations, and disagreed sharply on social and political issues.

Judging from the repertory that he played (solo piano works, piano concertos, much Brahms), and from the length and detail of his lessonbook entries, Brünauer was a considerable pianist, and commanded Schenker's serious attention. The lessons, two per week, appear to have been purely pianistic, with no sign of theoretical studies, and little sign of analytical studies of orchestral or chamber works before 1929, after which Brünauer prepared analytical graphs. Moreover, there is evidence that Schenker himself prepared materials in advance for Brünauer, and that his lessons with the latter were fertile for Schenker's own analytical thinking (OC 38/73, filed among papers for Der freie Satz, can be traced to lessons with Brünauer in 1929).

div.head: Correspondence with Schenker
div.p: From Schenker's diaries, it is clear that the two men corresponded a great deal; however, only three items survive, OC 52/636 (1925 – gathering information on sales of Der Tonwille), 44/15, 16 (1934 – written from the Grand Hotel and the Hotel Imperial, both in Vienna); additionally, OC 52/638 is a receipt from Albert J. Gutmann for payment of his 1924 subscription to Der Tonwille. One undated letter from Brünauer to Otto Vrieslander survives as OJ 71/37, and a carbon copy (with corrections in Jeanette Schenker's hand) survives of an article by him entitled "Die Urlinie: Eine Entgegnung," which was apparently a reply to an article by Walter Riezler in Die Musik for April 1930, as OJ 21/24. Works by Brünauer survive also as OC 41 (Waltz, Op.39/1) and OC 42 (arrangement of a keyboard piece by C. P. E. Bach, with Schenker's emendations).
